I can't identify with any of the four choices in the poll.
 
 The first choice--Palestinians are terrorists who should be eradicated from Israel--is too sweeping in its generalization of Palestinians. Some Palestinians are terrorists; many aren't. Those who commit violence against civilians, including leaders like Arafat who provide sanctuary to terrorists and fund their infrastructure, must be held accountable in order to neutralize their capacity to damage the peace process. Other Palestinians who simply want to go about the ordinary business of daily living--constructive employment, educating their children, etc--should not have to fear 'eradication.'
 
 The second choice--Israel, through ethnic cleansing has backed the Palestinains into a corner in which the only method of retaliation is terrorism--neither reflects history nor today's reality. The charge of ethnic cleansing cannot be substantiated in view of the fact that the Arab population of Israel has blossomed 10-fold, from 125,000 to 1.2 million people, in the 55 years since Israel was founded. Furthermore, if the Palestinians are backed into a corner, it's a self-inflicted consequence of repeated attempts to remove Israel from the map. Though the Palestinian leadership has recently given some lip service to recognizing Israel's right to exist, they have failed to match their words with deeds, and to this day continue to demand that millions of refugees be given the right to settle in the state of Israel rather than settle in their own proposed independent state of Palestine.
 
 The third choice--They're both wrong, one group are terrorists, the other are mini-Nazi's--is too exclusive. Mistakes have been made by individuals on both sides, but painting any large group with such a broad brush is a position prone to error. Under Arafat, the leadership of the Palestinian Authority has long been associated with terrorism and corruption, which makes life difficult not only for Israelis but also many Arabs who might otherwise build a prosperous society in relative peace alongside the Jewish state. Also, the "mini-Nazi" label is way out of bounds in the context of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
 
 The fourth choice--I back Israel because the US does--seems the least unpalatable of the group, but still it sounds too much like "my country, right or wrong." No thinking person will likely ever agree with their government's position on all issues, which makes this choice somewhat muddled. Besides, the U.S. government "backs" the Palestinians as well as Israel, since the Bush administration publicly supports the creation of an independent Palestinian state and has given roughly $400 million in both direct and indirect aid to the Palestinian people in the past two years. It's not very illuminating to say I back Israel--or I back the Palestinians--because the U.S. does. It would be more useful to state specific reasons why one supports one group more than the other.
 
 I cast my vote for 'none of the above.'

[QUOTE: Here's a quick history of the Israel/Palestine conflict - 
 Following WWII, the UN took a spot of land in the Middle East from other countries and gave it to Jews who were displaced by Hitler.]
 
 A history book should say something different. The UN didn't take land from "other countries." The land between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea was approximately 25% of the British Mandate for Palestine established after WWI when General Allenby defeated the Ottoman Turks who ruled the area for 400 years. (Most of the Palestine Mandate--the 75% east of the Jordan River--was given to the Arabs in the early 1920s and made off-limits to Jewish settlement.)
 
 There was no other internationally recognized sovereign power west of the Jordan R. except the British and certainly not any Arab country. That's why under international law the West Bank and Gaza Strip remain disputed territories to this day. Though the Arabs attempted--and failed--to assert sovereignty by force of arms, these territories remain in legal dispute and subject to negotiation between the two primary claimants, Israel and the Palestinian Arabs.
 
 The UN Partition Plan in 1947 sought to establish two states--one Jewish, one Arab. No resident in either proposed state would be required to move. When the British Mandate ended in May 1948, the state of Israel was proclaimed on land designated for the Jewish state. The Arabs refused to proclaim a state, instead choosing to wage a war of annihilation against Israel rather than establish an Arab state alongside the Jewish state.
 
 Regarding the comment that the UN gave the land to "Jews who were displaced by Hitler," it neglects to note that Jews were living in Palestine continuously for at least 2,500 years before Hitler was born. Early in the 19th century the Jewish population in Jerusalem exceeded the number of Christians or Muslims, as documented by the Ottoman census of 1844. Furthermore, waves of Sephardic and Oriental Jews from Arab and other countries outside Europe made their way to Israel. Though the European Jews were wealthier and better educated and organized, the Jewish state was intended for all Jews, not only those displaced by Hitler.
 
 [QUOTE: The Palestinians, who lived in the areas that were taken away, wanted their land back. Since Palestine was (and still is) not a country, they resorted to terrorism to try and force Israel to give some of the land back.]
 
 At the time of the UN partition plan, one-third of the population were Palestinian Jews. The Palestinian Arabs were given their own state alongside the Jewish state but declined it in favor of taking all the land, including the portion designated as a Jewish homeland. You appear to be trying to justify the Arab decision to resort to belligerence and terrorism. 
 
 Perhaps you will recall that for two decades--between 1948 and 1967--Israel posed no barrier to the establishment of an independent Arab state in the West Bank and Gaza, ruled by Jordan and Egypt. The collective goal of the Arab leadership was the total destruction of Israel. To better serve that goal, the Arab leaders kept the Palestinian refugees as a homeless people confined to miserable refugee camps rather than allow them to move out and establish their own state. It's true the Palestinians have suffered, but much of it was deliberately engineered by Arab leaders determined not to settle the issue in a manner that permitted the continued existence of the Jewish state. 
 
 [QUOTE: Palestine is to blame for the continued terror, but Israel is also to blame for the military retaliation that has not helped the situation.]
 
 On the contrary, Israel's military retaliation has helped accomplish something extraordinary. The Jewish state still exists--even thrives--despite repeated Arab attempts to destroy it. Why blame Israel for continuing to exist through self-defense? What do you suggest Israel do to help the situation?
 
 The occupation of Palestinian population centers will quickly end when the Arab leadership dismantles the terrorist infrastructure and sincerely accepts Israel's right to exist in peace. Are you aware that the U.S. military occupied parts of Japan for 27 years after WW2 ended. The Palestinian incitement of violence against Israel is yet to cease. Furthermore, unlike the U.S., Israel does not enjoy the protective buffer of two oceans and friendly neighbors.
 
 Most of Israel's population and industrial capacity is concentrated in a narrow region between the Mediterrean and the West Bank that is only nine miles at one point. Have you ever really tried to imagine the serious security concerns of a country that small, in a hostile, undemocratic neighborhood.

 Sorry to be obtuse, it was not intentional. I meant "by the way" and secondly I meant to say that the first prime minister quit because Arafat would NOT cooperate. Sorry I left the "not" out. It does change the meaning a tad. My point was simply to agree with you that Arafat is obstructionistic and a pain.

Where did you get that idea (that Arafat is a dictatorial ruler.) He is democratically elected.

 
 The evidence of Arafat's dictatorial rule is provided by Arafat himself. He is an autocrat who acts like a petty tyrant. He insists on his own way and will not defer to others. Even his parliament, the Palestinian Legislative Council (PLC), has recognized his corruption and contempt for the rule of law.
 
 You point out he was democratically elected, but you neglect to point out that after his election Arafat announced an indefinite freeze on future elections. The PLC has criticized Arafat for refusing to hold new elections, so your point about Arafat's election back in 1996 does not help you show that he isn't a dictator today who continues to repress his own people and make their lives miserable.
 
 This isn't the first time you argued the point that Arafat was democratically elected. I answered you then, but you seem to ignore the facts. Hitler also came into power in Germany through a democratic process, but will you also argue that Hitler was NOT a dictator. The important point is not whether Arafat was democratically elected, but what did Arafat DO with his executive power AFTER he was elected.
 
 In the free world people understand that the establishment of democratic national institutions requires more than the mechanism of elections alone. To properly ensure justice, peace and respect for human freedom and dignity, there must also be an independent judiciary and the freedoms of opinion, expression, information, assembly, and association.
 
 I noted previously that Attorney General Abu Rahma resigned after just nine months in office, citing Arafat's interference in the judicial process. The PNA judiciary, consisting of criminal, civil, and state security courts, are not independent. Critics of Arafat's government are routinely arrested and beaten. Independent newspapers and private television stations have been closed. Journalists are detained and assaulted. Restrictions on freedom of expression (like the anti-incitement decree #3 of 1998) have silenced the opposition.
 
 Not only does Arafat disregard the rulings of the High Court, he also ignores the elected parliament. For example, the PLC passed a Basic Law in 1997 to outline the separation between legislative and executive authority. Arafat's government has not approved it, presumably because it would curtail his authority. In 1999 a group of legislators signed a petition stating their grievances against the govn't: corruption, abuse of power, misuse of resources, human rights violations, and a dysfunctional political process. Arafat's security forces responded by harrassing, assaulting and arresting those who had signed the petition.
 
 These facts were stated previously, yet you seem to ignore them as you offer nothing more than the repetitious argument that Arafat was 'democratically elected.' In truth, Arafat dashed the hopes of the Palestinian people that democratic institutions would be established and sustained. There is no democracy under Arafat. He has snatched away legislative and judicial independence, thereby concentrating all political power in his executive authority. His rule is dictatorial, plain and simple.
Saddam Hussein was also elected...and we all know that that was absurd.

The state of Palestine is a state in name only, they really concentration camps.

 
 Palestine is not a "state", not even in name only. The Oslo Accords created a semi-autonomous Palestinian Authority, not a state with sovereign power.
 
 You previously wrote:
 
 
Palestine is a free and sovergin state. Arafat is a democratic elected leader. It is an independant state even recognized by Isreal.

 
 Why persist in this misconception? No country in the world yet recognizes an independent state of Palestine. Even the United Nations has not recognized any sovereign power in the West Bank and Gaza Strip since the British Mandate ended in 1948. Pretending otherwise won't change the facts. 
 
 
Those camps? They are Palestine, they are the disembodied real-estate of Palestine.

 
 No matter how you choose to describe the Palestinian refugee camps, the fact remains that all of them were established on Arab soil. It's shameful the way Arabs have treated their Palestinian brethren for more than 50 years. Even today the vast majority of Palestinian refugees are kept in miserable camps in Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan-- all Arab countries. The reason for this is that the Arab leadership is more interested in hurting Jews than helping Palestinian Arabs.

It is absolutly important that peace be achived in Palestine. There was a good chance with Rabin, there is no chance with Sharon.

 
 Rabin wasn't the only good chance. After Rabin was killed, Shimon Peres became prime minister. Peres was Rabin's partner in promoting the hopes of the Oslo Accords. Even when Rabin was prime minister, the problem for him and Peres is that Arafat did not act to disarm the terrorist groups and dismantle their infrastructure. Even today, Arafat continues to give money and sanctuary to terrorist groups.
 
 If it weren't for Arafat's latest attacks on the Jewish state, Sharon would not likely have been elected prime minister. Those attacks began when Barak was prime minister. Clinton, Barak, and Arafat met at Camp David to end the conflict once and for all. Arafat refused to negotiate in good faith. He returned home to unleash the violence of the Intifada. Arafat undermined the peace efforts of Israel's Labor party and set back the goal of an independent Palestinian state. The violence promoted by Arafat played a crucial role in bringing Sharon to power.
 
 
 
The injustice in Palestine has given the moral authority to convince the Islamic fundamentalist to kill US citizens.

 
 You are sanctioning the mass slaughter of innocent civilians. Sorry, but you do not have such "moral authority." If you choose to kill people solely because they are U.S. citizens, that is your choice, but it is still a murderous act. Your attempt to depict it as having some sort of moral authority rather serves to underscore the uncivilized nature of your belief system.
 
 
 
"...I swear to God that America will not live in peace before peace reigns in Palestine..."
 Osama bin Laden
 October 7, 2001

 
 The date of bin Laden's quote was October 2001, shortly after al-Qaeda's attack on New York and Washington DC. Bin Laden was hoping for support to shield him from an imminent U.S. attack on his terrorist training bases in Afghanistan. The only reason he mentioned "Palestine" is because he was trying to tap the support of anti-Zionists.
 
 Prior to 9-11, bin Laden didn't show any regard for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Even if Israel didn't exist, bin Laden would still have targeted U.S. interests because of our presence in Saudi Arabia. Do you know what is meant by 'red herring'? That's when someone introduces a new subject to divert attention from the truth. Bin Laden's reference to Palestine is simply a red herring.
 
 
 
Forget what you see on TV, the Isreali are not our friends:

 
 The URLs you provide do not show that Israel is not a friend. They merely show that friendly countries still spy on each other. Do you seriously think the U.S. doesn't spy on our allies in Canada, Europe, Asia, and elsewhere?
 
 Israel is not simply our friend but the BEST friend we have in the region. No country in the Middle East is a more reliable friend to the U.S. than Israel, which explains our shared value initiatives, as well as our economic and strategic cooperation.
 
 
 
This country missed an opportunity to be friends with most of the Muslim world.

 
 When Soviet Premier Kosygin asked President Johnson why the U.S. supports Israel when there are 80 million Arabs and only 3 million Jews, the President replied simply, "Because it is right."
 
 There has been no fundamental change in that view.

As I have said, Arafat as skillfully managed the conditions so he is always in power.

 
 You admit he's "always in power," yet you argue he's not a dictatorial ruler. There's a problem in the Arab world with lack of freedom and democracy. There are 22 member nations in the League of Arab States, and not a single democracy among them. The people who blame Israel for the problems in the Arab world aren't helping solve anything. Israel is merely the scapegoat for Arab leaders to divert attention from dealing with the real problems of how to better the lives of the Arab masses.
 
 
 
In power over what? Arafat in power of basically a clubhouse and political disscussion tea party.

 
 If only it were true that Arafat was merely a clubhouse leader who discussed politics over a cup of tea. Arafat in fact has billions of dollars at his disposal stashed away in Swiss bank accounts and invested in foreign real estate. Rather than use this money to raise the living standard of his people from their conditions of poverty, he uses it to fund terrorism and to arm the 40,000 men that comprise the dozen or so security services under his control. The U.S. alone has given Arafat's government over $200 million in aid the past two years. Who is watching how it is spent?
